29.text: 14 teams of distinguished alumni have entertained us

32.text: over the past few days with, on the whole,

34.text: an impressive display of what they know.

36.text: What many of them don't know, it turns out,

39.text: is when to use their buzzers in this contest and when not to.

42.text: But we've only been playing the game for 54 years,

45.text: and these things do take time to sink in.

47.text: But now, only the best two teams remain,

49.text: and in a little under half an hour,

51.text: one of them will become series champions,

55.text: than the right to look immensely pleased with themselves.

59.text: Now, the team from Leeds University had a very comfortable win

61.text: over the School of Oriental and African Studies

65.text: but they were trailing behind the University of Kent

69.text: When they finally got a grip and had put themselves on level pegging

73.text: at the gong, the tie-break question went their way.

76.text: They may never have been so pleased

78.text: to know about the Tigris and the Euphrates.

82.text: to introduce themselves for the last time.

86.text: I graduated from Leeds in 1984 with a degree in English literature,

90.text: and I now write novels for a living.

115.text: and I've been drawing political cartoons

123.text: The team from St Hilda's College Oxford

126.text: beat Magdalene College Cambridge in their first-round match

132.text: Then, in the rare spectacle of an all-female fixture,

135.text: they beat St Anne's College Oxford by 165 points to 75.

139.text: Let's meet them for the last time.

186.text: OK, the rules are unchanging on this contest,

615.text: "appalled at the amount of weight or flab one has gained".
